Solving the Hartree-Fock Equation

  • This is difficult to solve, as the potential operators are themselves functions of the eigenfunctions. One method is the self-consistent iterative technique
    1. Find initial values for the ψn(x⃗)\psi_n(\vec x)ψn​(x)﻿ by solving the single-particle problem h(x⃗))ψn(0)(x⃗)=ϵnψn(0)(x⃗)h(\vec x))\psi_n^{(0)}(\vec x)=\epsilon_n\psi_n^{(0)}(\vec x)h(x))ψn(0)​(x)=ϵn​ψn(0)​(x)﻿ numerically using basis states apropriate to the symmetry.
    1. Use the resulting eigenfunctions and the definitions of U^H\hat U_HU^H​﻿ and U^E\hat U_EU^E​﻿ to express H^\hat HH^﻿ as a matrix (the Fock matrix) using the same basis states.
    1. Diagonalise this matrix and find the eigenfunctions.
    1. Repeat steps 2 and 3 until the eigenfunctions are the same on each iteration (convergence).
  • Using only a small fraction of the eigenfunctions calculated in each iteration, this process can be made more stable. That is letting

Interpretation

  • The Hartree-Fock ground state energy, E0>EExactE_0>E^\text{Exact}E0​>EExact﻿.
    • The difference between the Hartree-Fock and exact ground state energies is the correlation energy.
  • The Lagrange multipliers ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​﻿ are addition energies.
  • Koopmans theorem gives the energy required to take one electron out (assuming wavefunctions are unchanged) is
  • Hartree-Fock theorem accounts for exchange interactions from the Pauli principle,, but electrons of opposite spin remain uncorrelated.

The Interacting Electron Gas

  • With high electron density (small rsr_srs​﻿), the kinetic energy is dominant and an electron gas behaves as an almost ideal non-interacting Fermi gas.
  • With intermediate electron density, the exchange energy causes full ferromagnetic alignment of electron spins with lower energy than the normal fluid (75<rs<10075<r_s<10075<rs​<100﻿).
  • With low electron density (rs>100r_s>100rs​>100﻿), electrons are trapped in the Coulomb potential of other electrons, become localised to minimise their Coulomb repulsion, and the system undergoes a metal-insulator transition (a Mott insulator).
    • In this regime, the free electron gas crystallises on a regular BCC lattice.
    • The energy of a classical electron crystal is given by
    • Consider the Wigner crystal as an infinite repetition of spherical unit cells, each containing a uniform positive charge with a single electron at its centre.
      • Finding the potential for each sphere and calculating E0=NUcellE_0=NU_\text{cell}E0​=NUcell​﻿ using Usphere=12∫r<rsaBd3r⃗ρ(r)Vsphere(r)U_\text{sphere}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{r<r_sa_B}d^3\vec r\rho(r)V_\text{sphere}(r)Usphere​=21​∫r<rs​aB​​d3rρ(r)Vsphere​(r)﻿ allows for the total energy of the cell to be found as EN=Ucell=−eVsphere(0)+Usphere=−1.8rsRy\frac{E}{N}=U_\text{cell}=-eV_\text{sphere}(0)+U_\text{sphere}=-\frac{1.8}{r_s}\text{Ry}NE​=Ucell​=−eVsphere​(0)+Usphere​=−rs​1.8​Ry﻿
      • Notably, EWignerN<EHEGN\frac{E_\text{Wigner}}{N}<\frac{E_\text{HEG}}{N}NEWigner​​<NEHEG​​﻿, so the variational principle gurantees a phase transition to the Wigner state as rs→∞r_s\rightarrow \inftyrs​→∞﻿. Note HEG denotes homogeneous electron gas, discussed before).
  • A Mott insulator is a material which according to conventional band theory, should be metallic, due to its partially filled electronic bands. However, it behave as an insulator due to strong electron-electron interactions.
    • In other words, is a material with sufficiently large on-site Coulomb repulsion and relative small electronic bandwidth. An example is NiO.

Electron Correlations: The Exchange-Correlation Hole

  • For two non-interacting electrons with the same spin in plane-wave states, their antisymmetrised real-space wavefunction is
  • Hence, the probability of finding one electron in volume d3r1d^3r_1d3r1​﻿ and the other in d3r2d^3r_2d3r2​﻿ is
  • This demonstrates that equal spin electrons avoid each other - this has an impact on screening.
  • For a Hartree-Fock gas, the exchange term gives (see slide 23)
  • This defines an exchange charge density - the extra charge density seen by a particular electron at rrr﻿ as a result of its exchange interaction with other electrons at r’r’r’﻿
  • Converting this to a k-space integral and performing the integral allows for calculation of an average exchange charge density over occupied states in the Fermi sphere. By adding this to the uniform Coulomb charge density, the total average charge density seen by a HF electron is found as
  • This reduced concentration of electrons with equal spin in the vicinity of an electron is the Exchange-Correlation hole.
    • HF does not include correlations for electrons with antiparallel spin. More advanced techniques such as Density Functional Theory do.
